awd_titl_txt: Numerical Analysis of Partial Differential Equation Constrained Optimization Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
Every process in nature tries to optimize certain quantities under the available resources. The limited available resources act as constraints and, for this reason, constrained optimization problems are ubiquitous in science and engineering. Such optimization problems are inherently nonlinear due to the presence of constraints. This makes the development and analysis of algorithms and computational techniques to simulate the relevant phenomena extremely challenging and of practical relevance. A systematic approach is needed to allocate resources, without violating constraints, and remain effective in minimizing cost. This project will lead to development of advanced, efficient algorithms to design micro- and nano-scale lab-on-chip devices, as well as novel materials with desired configuration and user specified properties. As an outcome of shape optimization tools, robust algorithms for image processing and structural design will be developed. A significant amount of effort will be devoted to develop new models for cardiac electrical response and diffusion of water molecules in brain tissue. 

Many of the partial differential equations (PDEs) that describe the constraints are geometric, nonlinear, and multiscale, with an unknown domain, i.e. free boundary problems (FBPs). This makes the development and analysis of numerical techniques for the solution of these problems challenging. This project focuses on constrained optimization problems with PDE constraints -- the so-called PDE constrained optimization problem. In fact, it aims to develop and study numerical techniques for a new collection of such problems for which classical ideas and methods do not work. They are: optimization with Stokes FBP (including surface tension) as constraint, problems where the Hessian appears in the cost functional, multilevel techniques for shape optimization and image segmentation problems, optimization with nonlocal (fractional) operators, and degenerate parabolic equations as constraints. The applications range from micro- to nano-scales, where surface effects dominate bulk effects. This will have impact in designing next generation lab-on-chip devices. By manipulating curvature, one can drive particles towards a desired assembly or a specific configuration. This will lead to highly sophisticated materials with user specified properties.  The multilevel techniques developed to solve shape optimization problems will provide a general tool to study inverse problems (acoustic scattering, for example), image processing, structural design, and fluid dynamics (for example, in aircraft design).

por.por_cntn:
Many problems in nature can be posed in an optimization framework. Moreover, several of the underlying physical processes are described using partial differential equations (PDEs). The goal of this project has been to study optimization problems with PDEs as constraints. We call such problems as PDE constrained optimization (PDECO) problems. In particular, within the project, we have worked on the following set of problems: 1) Fluid dynamics problems with free boundaries where it is essential to account for the geometry (curvature) of the (unknown) domain. These proposed ideas have been applied for the efficient design electrowetting on dielectric (EWOD) devices. 2) Shape optimization problems with shell structure acoustics with applications to design musical instruments such as violins. 3) PDECO problems with fractional/nonlocal PDEs as constraints with applications in geophysics, machine learning, and imaging science. 4) Optimization based reduced order models with applications to turbulence models. 5) Reduced order methods to search for gravitational waves (GWs). 6) We have created 3 open source software:

a) “GreedyCPP” https://bitbucket.org/sfield83/greedycpp/src/master/ for GWs search

b) PDECO https://bitbucket.org/harbirantil/pde_constrained_opt/src/master/ 

c) Fractional PDEs https://bitbucket.org/harbirantil/frac_poisson_nhbc/src/master/

 

Optimization with free boundary problems (FBPs) has enabled us to create nonstandard analysis tools. New finite element techniques to approximate these problems has improved our understanding of nonlinear problems and how to preserve their structure at the discrete level. 

We have formulated fractional PDEs in weighted spaces with degenerate weights. A wide class of inverse problems fall under this category, for instance, problems with pointwise sources. 

New analysis tools have been developed to analyze fractional semilinear and quasilinear PDEs and subsequently their control. These techniques are applicable to a wider class of problems. 

The optimization problems for nonlocal PDEs have borrowed ideas from nonlinear interpolation theory, potential theory and harmonic analysis.

 

The open source software generated during this project "Greedycpp" is already being used by the Gravitational Wave community. In addition, we have created two additional open source software to solve PDECO and fractional PDEs.

Optimization problems with surface tension is a new mathematical field, with potentially greater consequences in enhancing our understanding of the micro and nano-scales where surface effects dominate bulk effects. Our work will have impact in designing next generation lab-on-chip devices, forensics, etc.

Nonlocal problems are becoming increasingly important in science and engineering. We have shown that they give rise to better models in geophysics and imaging science. 

FBPs appear in fluid mechanics, a chief example being lab-on-chip devices, but they also arise in materials science, image processing, biology, porous media, finance, shape optimization, etc. 

During the proposal period, the PI has organized 7 minisymposia at national and international meetings. In addition, he has organized 3 major conferences and 4 summer schools. He also taught at 3 summer schools (Spain, Munich, USA). The PI has given 85 talks at the national and international conferences. Moreover, the PI has created 5 special topics courses at the graduate level. The project has resulted in 30 publications and in addition 1 book. The PI has supervised 3 undergraduate students, 3 MS students, and 3 postdocs. In addition, a female student PhD student has been supported by the project.
